newsitem.title: GERMANY: German call money eases after Buba repo injection.
newsitem.headline: German call money eases after Buba repo injection.

text.p: German call money eased slightly in Wednesday trading after the Bundesbank injected additional funds into the money market at its weekly securities repurchase tender.
Overnight funds were approaching three percent after trading near 3.10 percent on Tuesday, dealers said.

The Bundesbank this morning injected 71.1 billion marks at a fixed three percent rate into the money market to replace a 69 billion mark repo pact expiring at a fixed 3.30 percent rate. Dealers said the Bundesbank had likely realised that there some liquidity tightness and acted accordingly.
Dealers said the step had helped money market conditions normalise again, bringing the rate closer to where it should be.
Banks' holdings at the Bundesbank totalled 38.6 billion marks on Tuesday compared with 38.7 billion marks one day earlier.
The monthly average eased slightly to 39.4 billion marks compared with 39.9 billion marks.
Banks did not make any Lombard borrowings.
The Frankfurt Interbank Overnight Average was set at 3.10433 percent compared with 3.14067 percent on Tuesday.
